title: How to Build in Web3
summary: This is a technical course for Builders who look to build in Web3 space.
details:
In this course, we cover the following
1) Chapter 1 - The Blockchain Revolution
2) Chapter 2 - Strategy Design
3) Chapter 3 - Network Effects
4) Chapter 4 - Design for Web3
5) Chapter 5 - Mechanism Design
6) Chapter 6 - Partnership Development
7) Chapter 7 - Scaling Operations

topics.title: The Blockchain Revolution
topics.details:
### About this chapter
This is the first lesson of Kleros course "How to Build in Web3". It's taught by Federico Ast, co-founder and President at the Kleros Cooperative.

In this lesson, you will learn the key concepts of the blockchain revolution: why Web3 is a new iteration of the Internet and how it is different from Web2, the Internet controlled by the big tech companies of Silicon Valley.


In this link, you can access the materials for the lesson: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1b...
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bdDpWAl5LvkFj-x7bovAQHHtcQttw6YdTqF3cEyWxu0/edit

Download the slide deck used in the video here:
https://www.slideshare.net/FedericoAst/how-to-build-in-web3-session-1-the-blockchain-revolution-federico-ast

Want to build on Web3? Apply to the Kleros Incubator here!
https://kleros.io/incubator/

choices.content: The 2000 dot-com crash.
The 2008 Global Financial Crisis (aka Great Recession).
The 1929 stock market crash at the start of the Great Depression.

questions.content: Which event precipitated the rise of Bitcoin and the Blockchain Revolution?

choices.content: They are great for sourcing great music.
They draw us in with free services but take advantage of our personal data and intercepts our transactions.
They sound off alarms when malicious activities happen on their networks.

questions.content: Why are Web2 platforms referred to as 'siren servers' by Jaron Lanier in his book 'Who Owns the Future'?

choices.content: Protocols become more 'dense' as they are built on by other protocol/projects, and will tend to settle towards the bottom of the Protocol Sink.
The more trustless, permissionless and credibly neutral a protocol is the further it can scale to become a global platform.
The thesis predicts that Web3 protocols will never reach the scale of their Web2 counterparts.
The resting place of a protocol in the Protocol Sink is determined by its utility and surface area for attack.

questions.content: Which of the following describes the Protocol Sink Thesis for crypto-systems proposed by Ryan Sean Adam? Select all that are correct.

choices.content: Utility / (Attack Surface)^2
Utility / Attack Surface
Utility x Attack Surface

questions.content: Which of the following is the correct definition of Protocol Density?

choices.content: There is less supplier risk, as services built in a decentralized manner are uncensorable and more transparent.
The response time of decentralized API services are definitely better than Web2 alternatives.
The cost and business models of the suppliers are more attuned towards the interests of the customers, and are less likely to tend towards rent-seeking behaviour as they scale.

questions.content: What are some benefits of building on Web3 solutions instead of their Web2 counterparts?

choices.content: A protocol is credibly neutral if it is not created by a single centralized entity.
Anything can be considered credibly neutral if it does not extract rent and payments from its users.
A credible neutral protocol is built on rules that doesn't arbitrarily benefit some group of users over others.

questions.content: What is a credibly neutral protocol?

In this lesson, you will have a short introduction to the course and you will learn the key concepts of the blockchain revolution: why Web3 is a new iteration of the Internet and how it is different from Web2, the Internet controlled by the big tech companies of Silicon Valley.


### Homework and further readings
#### Homework
The homework for this lesson is to read the materials below to build an understanding of Web3.

#### Further readings

- Chris Dixon. “[Why Decentralization Matters](https://onezero.medium.com/why-decentralization-matters-5e3f79f7638e)”. A16z blog.

- Jesse Walden. “[Crypto’s Business Model is Familiar. What Isn’t is Who Benefits](https://future.com/crypto-business-model/)”. Future.

- Joel Monegro and Chris Burniske. “[Placeholder Investment Thesis Summary](https://www.placeholder.vc/blog/2018/2/13/thesis-summary)”. Placeholder.

- Vitalik Buterin. “[Credible Neutrality as a Guiding Principle”](https://nakamoto.com/credible-neutrality/). Nakamoto. 2020.
- Glen Weyl, Puja Ohlhaver and Vitalik Buterin. [Decentralized Society: Finding Web3's Soul](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4105763).

topics.title: Network Effects
topics.details: Web3 protocols typically operate as multi-sided platforms connecting different types of users. Their growth potential typically depends on their ability to create network effects. In this lesson, you will learn how to study your market structure and your different user types in order to create a network effects strategy.

questions.content: Why is it important to understand network effects in Web3?

choices.content: It helps you build products that are resistant to network outages.
It helps you develop a growth strategy for your product.
It helps explain how an early start can help you build a moat that protects you against competition.
The network is only as strong as its weakest link.
The value of a network grows exponentially as more people join.
A Metcalfe network will be able to continue to operate even if parts of it are cut off from the rest.

questions.content: What is the Metcalfe's Law in the field of networks?

choices.content: An on-demand food delivery service.
A decentralized peer-to-peer messaging service.
An NFT platform marketplace.
A social network platform.

questions.content: Which of these businesses are likely to be able to take advantage of network effects when delivering value to their users?

choices.content: YouTube growing in usage as the speed of internet networks grow globally.
Ethereum growing as more and more interdependent dApps are built on top of it.
Telegram growing in user base as more and more people invite their friends to the platform.

questions.content: Which of the following are examples of direct network effects?

choices.content: Kleros growing in integrations and jury size, as long-time jurors go on to start their own projects to use Kleros, and vice versa.
YouTube growing in usage due to consumers, advertisers and content producers using it as a platform to consume each other's content and information.
DoorDash being able to offer super fast delivery due to the network of highways available in the United States.

questions.content: Which of the following are examples of indirect network effects?

choices.content: It can be a solution to the so-called 'Cold Start' problem.
It ensures long term 'stickiness' of your platform.
It is more suitable for platforms with passive user participation than those needing active user participation.

questions.content: Which of the following are true about using token incentives for early adopters of your service?

choices.content: Airdropping tokens to users of a new NFT marketplace when new traders/users do not provide additional direct value to the existing users.

Using tokens to compensate early DeFi liquidity providers for potential impermanent losses, as the fees from an increasing user base can eventually take over as the primary revenue source for liquidity providers in the long term.
Giving out tokens to offset gas fees on a DeFi platform when gas fees will only continue to increase in the future.

questions.content: In which of the following are examples of good usage of token incentives to kick off adoption?

In this lesson, you will learn how to design your blockchain projects. Plinio, who is the lead UX designer at Kleros covers various topics like human-centered design, web3 design principles, and UX research for web3. 

The video emphasizes the importance of having a user-centered and cyclical design process and introduces the Jobs to be Done methodology as a useful tool in the ideation process.
readings.title: Lesson 4 - Design for Web3

questions.content: What is the design process described in the tutorial?

choices.content: Linear and user-centric
Linear and technology-centric
Cyclical and user-centric
Cyclical and technology-centric

questions.content: What is the "jobs to be done" methodology used in the design process?

choices.content: To identify pain points in the user experience
To classify insights in order of satisfaction and importance
To understand the outcomes that customers want to achieve with a product
To explore solutions to a problem

questions.content: What is the main principle of Brad Frost's Atomic Methodology?

choices.content: Continuously seeking improvements
Focusing on the technical aspects of the product
Breaking down the complex design into smaller, reusable parts
Prioritizing the needs of the business over the needs of the users

readings.details: In this chapter, Guangmian who is the Integrations Manager at Kleros talks about the integration design for growth. He discusses how barriers can be decreased for more adoption by designing for “unilateral adoption” and cross and up-selling through methods like progressive enhancement and graceful degradation.

questions.content: What is the typical distribution of prospects in the B2B world according to the presentation?

choices.content: Most prospects are small and agile, but there are a few large companies that represent over 50% of your addressable market
Most prospects are large and hard to approach, but there are a few small and agile companies
The majority of prospects are medium-sized and easy to approach
There is no specific distribution of prospects in the B2B world

questions.content: Which statement holds true about the concept of unilateral adoption?

choices.content: Requiring cooperation from both parties for integration
Only allowing one party to integrate at a time
Focusing on integration within one's own organization
Allowing either party to integrate without the cooperation of the other

questions.content: How can a company decrease barriers to adoption and increase the chances of breaking into a large market segment?

choices.content: By requiring cooperation from both parties for integration
By focusing on unilateral adoption and making integrations built and giftable
By only allowing one party to integrate at a time
By focusing on integration within one's own organization

questions.content: What is the main difference between inter-organizational and intra-organizational integrations?

choices.content: Inter-organizational integrations require cooperation from both parties, while intra-organizational integrations do not
Inter-organizational integrations are focused on external partners, while intra-organizational integrations focus on internal stakeholders
Inter-organizational integrations are more complex, while intra-organizational integrations are simpler
Inter-organizational integrations are focused on open-source projects, while intra-organizational integrations are focused on proprietary projects

questions.content: How does progressive enhancement help with cross-selling and upselling in integration design?

choices.content: It forces customers to purchase all features of a product at once
It limits the number of features a customer can use
It allows customers to start with any subset of your products, and upgrade their integration with a product as they see fit
It is not related to cross-selling and upselling

readings.details: This lesson covers the very important topic of the Scalability of Operations in a Web3 startup and takes the discussion of Efficiency vs Redundancy in depth and ways to increase both of them.
readings.title: Lesson 7 - Scaling Operations

questions.content: What are the three constants of operations?

choices.content: Efficiency, redundancy, and scalability
Product development, marketing, and customer support
Sales, finance, and human resources
People, processes, and tools

questions.content: What is the Production Possibility Frontier?

choices.content: A concept that talks about the maximum efficiency and redundancy of an organization
A concept that talks about the financial performance of an organization
A concept that talks about the limitations to the production of an organization
A  concept that talks about the scalability of an organization

questions.content: Which of the following are the correct ways to increase Redundancy?

choices.content: Increase and improve documentation
Increase permission dependency
Procure only a single solution for a problem
Limit the complexity and number of products

questions.content: Which of the following cannot be a way to increase Efficiency?

choices.content: Encourage more self-sufficiency
Allow more self-determination
Hire more people
Outsource non-essential functions

questions.content: What is the idea behind 'griefing factors'?

choices.content: The profit that an attacker makes by harming others
The cost that an attacker takes on to harm the platform
The harm that an attacker does to others in the platform in terms of the cost they do to themselves
The delay caused by an attacker on the platform

questions.content: What is the problem of front running in a blockchain platform?

choices.content: Attackers manipulate applications by having their transactions confirmed ahead of those of other actors
Users can double spend using the same transaction
Miners can collude to manipulate the blockchain
Transactions can be delayed due to network congestion

questions.content: What is a potential drawback of using a time-weighted average as an oracle?

choices.content: It may not be accurate enough
It may be slow to update to new information
It may be too expensive
It may be too complex to implement
